title: Monday, 24th July, 2017

PM11:04am

11:04 am
PM11:04am

http://visual.ons....cost-of-chocolate/

PM11:04am

No, you’re not imagining it – some of your favourite sweets really are shrinking. In November 2016, Toblerone chocolate bars reduced in size by about 10%, provoking outrage online. And Maltesers, M&Ms and Minstrels have gone the same way.

It’s a phenomenon known as “shrinkflation” – where manufacturers reduce the package size of household goods while keeping the price the same.

But it’s not just chocolate bars. Over the last few years, journalists have found examples of loo roll, coffee, fruit juice, sausages, beer and chips getting smaller without getting any cheaper.

PM11:05am

But what you want to know is whether the ONS takes shinkflation into account when calculating the headline inflation rate

11:05 am
PM11:05am

And the answer is yes

PM11:05am

Here's the whole methodology

PM11:05am

https://www.ons.go...uary2012tojune2017

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Shrinkflation is a term used to describe the business practice of changing the physical weight of a product, while keeping its price constant. The “shrink” part of the term refers to the change in package size, typically a reduction, whereas the latter part of the word refers to inflation – the rise in the general price level. If products “shrink” in size, inflation rises even if prices stay constant, as consumers pay the same amount of money for less of the good. In order to more accurately measure inflation, we use quality adjustment processes to isolate price movements from the changes in product’s weight or quality.

11:16 am

BE11:17am

Let me get some comment on this latest blowup.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Credit Suisse.

BE11:17am

1H profit warning, lower estimates and TP materially, reiterate Underperform. On 21st Jul (Fri after market close), GTO
announced prelim results where it noted (i) Q2 sales at Eu742mn (+14% qoq/-8% yoy/-9% yoy at constant FX) vs. CS/cons
at Eu786mn/Eu754mn, and (ii) 1H17 EBIT at Eu93mn (~7% margin) vs. old guidance of Eu90-100mn and CS/cons at
Eu107mn/Eu98mn. In terms of guidance, GTO expects (i) 2H sales to be flat yoy at constant FX (implying Eu1.63bn vs.
CS/cons at Eu1.71bn), and (ii) 2H EBIT of Eu200-230mn vs. old guidance of Eu300-350mn and CS/cons at
Eu286mn/Eu311mn. This weakness is due to continued weakness in Payments and SIM cards. Following this, we lower
our below-consensus sales and 2017 and 2018 EPS estimates by 5% and 8%, and 25% and 32%. We also lower our TP to
Eu30 (from Eu41), and given our structural concerns on growth and margins, we reiterate our Underperform rating.
 US EMV and SIM cards trends continue to worsen. Following ~10% yoy declines in SIM cards in recent quarters, we
believe that Q2 decline worsened to ~20%, something we believe will continue into 2H. On EMV, US remained a drag with
overall Payments sales likely declining in the 20-25% range vs. 14% decline in Q1. We continue to see both these
businesses (accounting for ~45% of sales) will continue to see double-digit declines given our view of limited unit growth
and pricing pressures, something we flagged in detail in our recent note titled Gemalto: Structural concerns, EBIT guidance
still at risk.
 Concerning EBIT impact from sales miss. What is more concerning is that the revised 2H guidance implies that around
Eu100mn of sales pressure is leading to Eu110mn of cut to EBIT guidance. This to us clearly suggests that i) GMs are
under pressure (we estimate 200bp/300bp down yoy in 1H/2H17), a trend likely to continue (even intensify given pricing
comments from peers), and ii) no benefit from Eu50mn cost-cutting plan announced at Q1 earnings.
 Lowering TP to Eu30. Our TP of Eu30 is based on average of (i) 1.2x EV/sales on 2018 estimates (incl. 3M Identity), and
(ii) P/E multiple of 13.0x for 2018 EPS of Eu2.35.

BE11:18am

Sorry for the lumpy formatting. I'm on a Mac and don't know how to use it.

11:19 am

PM11:19am

B&M European Value Retail SA (BME:LSE): Last: 352.10, up 11.2 (+3.29%), High: 358.50, Low: 351.80, Volume: 4.98m
PM11:21am

But it's a nice idea, surely

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Followed by the Telegraph, speaking to "sources" at Asda who say, "nope, not interested".

BE11:22am

(It's weird, incidentally, that no other paper has matched the Telegraph story. But that's an issue better talked about off air, perhaps.)

BE11:23am

Anyway, the stories can co-exist. Asda could've had an early look and then decided not to do anything more with the idea. That seems to be the gist of it.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

In terms of making sense .... not really.

BE11:24am

Does Wal-Mart want more exposure to the UK?

BE11:24am

Does it wasn't to double down on the Asda investment?

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Would it rather put £4bn or whatever into Asda pricing? Because surely Asda doesn't really have a shortage of non-food, nor space to put it in.

BE11:25am

So why buy B&M? The only possible reason I could think of would be management succession planning via acquisition.

BE11:26am

But that's a rather pricey way to do it, and B&M's management isn't exactly Wal-Mart culture.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Anyway, have some sell side to say I'm wrong.

BE11:26am

RBC

BE11:26am

While we see some benefits to this acquisition (e.g. a stronger local convenience presence in the UK), we believe any positives would be more than offset by the following factors:

We believe buying B&M would disrupt Asda’s price and range architecture. B&M’s business model is based on buying narrow (5,500 SKUs) and buying deep to drive value in its products. Our latest pricing survey shows B&M is on average c.6% cheaper than Asda and any acquisition could lead to downwards pricing pressure on Asda’s core grocery range.
Asda would most likely cannibalise its own food and general merchandise offer in the UK given B&M’s product mix of c.15% ambient food and c.25% FMCG.
Walmart has not indicated it sees the UK discount as a strategic priority, instead Walmart has been focusing on online initiatives in the US. B&M’s lack of online exposure would not give Asda access to a Sainsbury's/Argos-style click-and-collect offer.
The implied valuation premium for an acquisition would add to the risk of it not generating an acceptable return. For example a price of 440p, as mooted in the article, would equate to a P/E of 30x FY17 EPS.

Notwithstanding the above, we believe B&M is a well-positioned discounter and has an attractive growth story in its own right. As featured in our deep dive report on discount retailers, B&M is benefiting from a shift to value driven by a squeeze on UK consumer purchasing power, which along with better execution and increasing food price inflation should lead to a stronger LFL sales trend. B&M is managing margin pressures well, with upward revisions to store roll-out targets and potential acquisitions on the horizon. As such we reiterate our Outperform rating on B&M.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Shore.

BE11:27am

Quite what Asda/Wal-Mart make of matters remains to be seen. What we can say though is that since Sainsbury's^ (SBRY, Buy) acquisition of Argos the UK food retailers have entered a new phase of merger & acquisition ('M&A') activity. That phasing reflects demonstrable commercial stabilisation by new management following on from the collapse of earnings after the well documented misreading of the rise of the limited assortment discounters (LADs).

So, following on from the Argos acquisition, which we all along felt Asda should have acquired due to much greater customer symmetry than was the case with Sainsbury's, investors have seen Tesco# (TSCO, Hold) seek to merge with Booker^ (BOK, Sell) and further speculation that Sainsbury may follow suit in the wholesale channel and possibly buy NISA.

BE11:28am

ccordingly, given Asda's trading challenges in UK grocery in particular, where it has lost market share, especially suffered to the LADs and saw Sainsbury acquire Argos in general merchandising, it is not wholly surprising or fanciful that the Leeds based group should at least run the slide rule over its Speke based competitor.

Whilst admittedly putting the cart before the horse, B&M would bring great capability in general merchandise value retailing for Asda, with its strong range, authority, pricing and space growth, whilst providing George, Asda's excellent apparel brand, the scope for space growth in largely complementary locations. B&M is also increasingly effective in grocery, we should add.

Cost synergies would be potentially evident in central overheads, sourcing and logistics from such an acquisition albeit at the purported Sunday Times valuation of £4.4bn, which we feel is somewhat formulaic rather than a firm figure, such synergies would be necessary as B&M Stores' shares already carried a deservedly fulsome valuation.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

There is also the matter of the UK Competition & Markets Authority ('CMA'), which is currently investigating the Tesco-Booker merger but has some bad form in this space, most notably what we believe to be its disgraceful and incompetent handling of the Poundland-99p acquisition, which we overlaps to some degree potentially into the high street value space of B&M.

So, we return to the matter of the story at hand. We cannot know if Asda is advanced in its thinking on a B&M acquisition and any engagement at whatever level. We may know a little bit more today, through forced disclosures, if there is any smoke without fire. Whilst so, regardless of the individual reality of any interest at this time, the story is likely to at least temporarily mark up B&M's shares partially or fully placing the company 'in-play' whilst causing an ongoing swell of speculation surrounding associated and complementary M&A activity, both for public and private stocks, in the UK grocery and general merchandising arena.

PM11:29am

Do we have an ongoing swell??

PM11:29am

I'm not sure we do

11:29 am
PM11:29am

Well, there's Morrisons I guess

WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 251.00, up 1.7 (+0.68%), High: 251.02, Low: 248.40, Volume: 3.34m

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Here's that Telegraph report, by the way. http://www.telegra...takeover-interest/

BE11:31am

One assumes the Panel would not be pleased with senior Asda sources if Ashley Armstrong has been mislead here.

BE11:31am

So, it ain't happening. Probably.

11:31 am
undefined
BE11:32am

What else? Ryanair was mentioned earlier, I think.

PM11:32am

Yeah

11:32 am
Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 17.57, down 0.535 (-2.96%), High: 17.90, Low: 17.01, Volume: 2.15m
PM11:33am

Figs already, but the outlook less so

BE11:33am

Similar to every other airline, a small caution on yields.

11:33 am
PM11:33am

https://www.invest...1707240700048170L/

BE11:33am

No explicit change to guidance, but as we know from everyone else cheap fuel is keeping marginal operators in the air.

BE11:34am

Which drives down ticket prices and yada yada yada.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Panmure incoming.

PM11:01am

Welcome to ML

BE11:34am

8% Q1 ‘beat’ (April-June). Net profit of €397m, +55% YoY, is 8% ahead of €366m consensus (PGe €361m). Q1 average fares rose by 1%, better than PGe -2%, and compared to reiterated H1 guidance of -5%. Management call out Easter timing benefit being particularly strong, offsetting adverse GBP and lower bag revenue, with pax growth of 12%. Encouragingly, ex-fuel unit costs were down 3% YoY, with total unit costs (inc. fuel) down 6%.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

FY18 guidance is unchanged, for net profit of €1.40-€1.45bn (+8% YoY at mid-point). But we suspect consensus (currently €1,488m, PGe €1,478m) will start to push through €1.5bn assuming robust July/August traffic prints later in the summer. FY passenger guidance is edged up to 131m (from 130m), +8% YoY with flat 94% load factors. H1 fare guidance of -5% implies peak Q2 fares (July-September) down 8% which seems aggressive, but with high visibility at this stage we assume bag revenue is down steeply as more customers switch to the 2 free carry-on bag policy. H2 fare guidance of -8% incorporates the usual caution over low winter visibility (and echoes easyJet’s rhetoric). Ex-fuel unit costs guidance of down 1% could prove overly cautious given -3% achieved in Q1 and high capacity growth.

BE11:35am

Valuation & Recommendation. Our €20.0 TP equates to 16x PE for FY18 and 10.5x lease- adjusted EV/EBITDAR, towards the top of Ryanair’s historic range, and ahead of any competitor airline valuation we can think of, but is justified by increasing confidence in the sustainability of profitable growth and cash generation/return to shareholders. Our BUY rating is predicated on cost leadership, plus margin leadership plus growth leadership resulting in a structural leadership position for Ryanair. Our analysis provides comfort on all three fronts, and recent initiatives have generally strengthened that view, with ancillary revenue performance now targeted at 30% of revenue by 2020 (with Ryanair Rooms and Holidays development still at early stages); connecting Air Europa long-haul flights through Rome Fiumicino; and incremental growth opportunities from the restructuring of legacy airlines like Airberlin, Alitalia and LOT. Reiterate BUY.

BE11:35am

And RBC, briefly.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Longer term, we think (still) lower market fuel costs amplify the operating cost differential (in Ryanair's favour) on other cost items, thus increasing the company's competitive advantage on opex (as well as on unit capital costs - i.e. procurement gains on fleet, and on financing). Cost alone does not create a winner, but we think it does when combined with further product, revenue and customer retention initiatives which can generate sustained upside.

PM11:36am

I see it's hiking its base at Frankfurt -- from 2 to 7 aircraft

BE11:36am

14x PER multiple longer term total return credentials still strong: March 2018E RBCe PER multiple is 14x (8% below long-term 5 and 10 year median 15.3x-15.4x) and EV/EBITDAR close to 9.2x vs 5 year median 9.7x. The 5 years’ ahead EV/EBITDAR at 5.6x implies upside to reach a €30/share by then – offering 5 year 11%-12% return CAGR prospects. In a structural growth, disruptor name this means 3-5 year focused investors should still see meaningful upside returns, even if the company just delivers on base forecasts. (Historically it has beaten goals by greater than 10% over 2006-2016, which if seen in future would compound up total return potential).

11:36 am
PM11:36am

Interesting to see how Frankfurt grows, which lots of money being physically moved there

BE11:37am

Never been to Frankfurt. Is it nice?

PM11:37am

I haven't either. So I don't know.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Fair enough. Over to you, rabble.

undefined
PM11:38am

Arash popped up on the right, mentioning this WebMD stuff

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Have you followed this?

PM11:38am

KKR agreed terms

BE11:38am

Hooray! It's been a bit of a thorn, the WebMD story.

11:38 am
PM11:38am

$66.30 a share

BE11:39am

Story was first around -- in a highly credible form, I mean, rather than just rumours -- in January 2016

BE11:40am

We strayed on a lot of detail about the process.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Did a story, got an on-the-record denial.

BE11:40am

Which is always painful.

PM11:41am

Indeed

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Anyway, spin forward a year and it looks like they're finally completing the sale process that absolutely totally wasn't underway when we wrote about it.

undefined
BE11:43am

@explorer, I can recommend you some excellent casinos that'll cost you just as much as an interest in Carillion.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

With the advantage that they'll get you drunk while taking your money.

PM11:43am

It needs to raise money. It won't do that at the market price.

BE11:44am

There's some pretty good sellside saying that, more or less.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Canaccord, firstly.

BE11:44am

Pursuant to Carillion's parlous H1 trading update (£845m contract receivables provision, elevated net debt, dividend suspension, CEO exit, strategic review), we downgrade estimates and reiterate our SELL stance with a revised target price of 20p (from 200p). Notwithstanding a flurry of recent contract awards, which speak loudly to the pedigree and various world-class capabilities and technical competencies which exist within the company, we continue to see material downside in the equity value of the group.

BE11:44am

The company is facing a major liquidity crisis which will, in our view, require significant capital restructuring. Successful delivery of the current balance sheet repair initiatives (including augmented recovery of receivables, exit from certain construction markets) may itself be compromised by the perceived funding gap.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

An equity based funding solution is likely to prove challenging:
Interests of other stakeholders including banks and pension trustees (net deficit £587m, double the market cap) may impose conditionality.
Lack of permanent CEO turnaround specialist (may not be in situ soon).
Scope for further provisions/write-downs pursuant to EY strategic review (i.e. forecasts not secure and thus scale of funding requirement unclear). A formal update is not scheduled before the interims in (now "late") September.
Given the 80% price destruction over the last two years, current holders may not wish to exercise their pre-emption in which instance the strike price for new shares will be dictated by sub-underwriters and potentially very dilutive. Using a base assumption of a £500m rights issue (2.4x EBITDA, reducing net debt/EBITDA to 1.1x) we model for a spectrum of scenarios from a 7 for 6 at 100p down to a 12 for 1 at 10p, which constitute potential dilution to existing shareholders of between 55% and 93%.

BE11:45am

So you basically want a bid for all or parts, likely in combination with a debt-for-equity swap.

BE11:46am

Will there be much for equity holders in that outcome? Well, why would there be?

11:45 am
BE11:46am

This remains a very binary situation with the equity value highly geared to the quantum of net debt. Should the company over-deliver on the receivables recovery plan within the existing provision alongside its other balance sheet repair measures (by say £100m versus our forecast) then the shares could move back above 100p quite quickly (albeit we are unlikely to gain clarity on progress made before September). Any deterioration versus our admittedly cautious forecast leaves the existing equity value in peril. We expect the next few weeks will see continued price volatility and the net performance outcome could be extreme. Our SELL recommendation and 20p target price (equivalent to a further £200m balance sheet deterioration OR 6 for 1 rights to raise £500m) reflects the balance of risks, as we see them, for equity holders.

BE11:47am

Kevin Cammack at Cenkos did an excellent note last week in which he said, in effect, "give up"

BE11:47am

These are chastened times for Carillion; £845m of contract loss provisions have massacred shareholders’ funds, already high debt levels have worsened, the CEO has gone and Shorts still dominate the shareholder list. I find it virtually impossible to put a value on the equity within a range that is useful to investors and frankly until such time as the balance sheet is secured, there is no way of judging what the structure of the group or its earnings potential into recovery will be. The short-term will be a bumpy ride and for want of an ‘I’ve no idea’ rating a Sell will have to prevail since, although I am inclined to believe Carillion will be salvaged in some shape or form, it is hard not to conjecture that the existing equity will be worth any more than 40p-50p per share.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

"or want of an ‘I’ve no idea’ rating a Sell will have to prevail"

BE11:47am

Where does Carillion go to find such a large injection into the balance sheet given that its market cap is now only c£300m? A debt for equity swop looks extremely hard to deliver given the diversity of its lending and a straight equity re-financing will be massively dilutive. Neither is it asset rich for disposals and a White Knight will have to take on not just £900m of average net debt but also c£400m of reverse factoring and a £500m plus P/F deficit. Perhaps a mix of the above might breathe life back into Carillion.
n What’s worth saving? — Carillion’s services business with a strong UK infrastructure portfolio and heavy weight of MoD FM work, has a secured order book of £12.8bn rising to £23bn with frameworks and potential extensions. It has been amongst the most consistently profitable and higher margin of its peers and would be a sensible, attractive basis for a ‘phoenix’ Carillion.
n Fair Value? — My ‘fair value’ computation produces a figure of c70p for Carillion but I stress there is nothing ‘fair’ about this situation. Perhaps tellingly, the big short position in Carillion (28%) has not unwound since the loss revelations – and at the moment they have undeniably the best track record to follow.

BE11:48am

But that's enough of that. It's not even an equity story any more.

11:47 am
PM11:48am

Terrific stuff

undefined
BE11:48am

What else do we have?

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Reckitt statement

PM11:49am

Still suffering from this cyber attack

BE11:49am

200bp off sales growth!

11:49 am
PM11:50am

Just from the attack

BE11:50am

As we've said previously, Reckitt runs very hot. It's a no-fat business. It doesn't leave much room for stuff to go wrong.

BE11:51am

Which, to repeat ourselves once again, makes the multiple paid for the mustards to be ab-so-lutely nuts. There are no cost savings to extract there because it's Reckitt. Cost savings are all it does.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Anyway, have Investec.

BE11:51am

H117 lfl sales of -1% are in line with recently reduced guidance, albeit the market in W Europe slowed in Q2. Guidance of +2% for FY17 is maintained (but described as “challenging”). Mead lfl is guided to between -2% and flat for H217 (consistent with our modelling), although the operating margin on acquisition was below management expectations. Combined with a new provision of £318m related to the Indivior spin, we regard the statement as disappointing. Sell.

While H117 lfl sales and margins are in line with consensus expectations, and FY17 guidance is maintained (unsurprisingly, having been issued as recently as 6th July), and EPS at 131.4p is modestly ahead of the 128.1p consensus, there are some new areas of concern introduced in the H117 statement. Given that Russian performance was strong within the “rest of ENA”, we estimate that Western Europe sales fell 7-8% in Q2 as the market weakened – materially below our expectation despite the continued Scholl/Amope declines and the impact of the cyber attack.
Mead Johnson lfl sales guidance of -2% to flat in H2 is in line with our forecast. However, margins in Mead’s Q217 fell 500bps as a result of higher milk powder costs and higher rates of marketing support (by the previous management). While overall, Mead’s top line decline of 1% in Q2 showed improvement (Q1: -5%), trends remain volatile, with a deterioration in the US, Lat Am and Southern Asian markets. China improved, but we expect significant disruption around new regulations, coming into force on 1st January 2018.
While there are no additional provisions for the Korean Humidifier Sanitiser issue, a sizeable £318m charge against potential payments relating to the Indivior spin-off in December 2014 has been taken. Details have not been disclosed by the company.
Overall, the results and commentary are disappointing in our view, with increased risk to the bulls’ hopes of a quick pick up in performance at Reckitt.

BE11:52am

And UBS.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

B restated its P&L for the Food disposal, which makes it difficult to compare the results to consensus. RB Q2 LfL (-2%) was in-line with the press release from July. H1 EBIT margin was up +30bps, but this includes restatements, both incl. and excl. Foods. GM was up +10bps yet a Brand Equity Investment was cut -40bps YoY. H1 EPS of 131.4p (incl. Foods) was a 3% beat to consensus. RB has taken a £318m provision in respect of Indivior/DoJ discussions. We consider the quality of these results disappointing for a company like RB, and expect the stock to underperform today particularly given management's commentary around 2017 outlook

BE11:52am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
(1) RB still has "work to do on addressing the full implications of the cyber-attack", which might present further downside risk to expectations; (2) MJN H1 margin was down -500bps, weaker than RB "initially expected"; (3) Health LfL was -2% in H1 (-4% in Q2), which raises questions on this division's dependence on a few brands; (4) declining sales in India compared unfavourably to Unilever's flat volumes/positive LfL in the country; and (5) working cap was -14% of sales (pro-forma) despite the MJN deal, which is a very solid level in the industry.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
RB has reiterated its +2% LfL guidance for the Core business, calling this "a challenging target". Core operating margin continues to make "satisfactory progress" and the mid-term guidance for moderate expansion was reiterated. For MJN, RB is guiding to -2% to flat LfL growth in H2 (UBSe flat), noting that "operating margin prior to closing was slightly weaker than initially expected". Press release did not include any comments on Core / MJN EBIT margin guidance for 2017. We think this guidance is weaker than what many investors were prepared for, and could drive some downgrades (ex-FX).
Valuation: and how would we expect investors to react?
Despite the H1 EPS beat, we expect the shares to underperform today – the guidance (and the cautious commentary around it) along with the £318m provision related to Indivior (another "one-off") are disappointing. At 21.5x 18E PE, RB trades at a small premium to EU Staples. We think this premium might get challenged today.

PM11:55am

1H17: Weak Topline, Strong Margins at RB and Improving Topline, Weak Margins at MJN. In Q2 Reckitt saw headwinds across segments in its core business culminating in the cyber-attack in June, leading to the 6th July pre-announcement: -2% LFL in 2Q17 (-1% for 1H17) for group sales. De-stocking due to tax changes (GST) in India, the tail end of the failed Scholl/Amopé innovation and consumer sentiment in South Korea also contributed to a soft quarter for sales. EBIT margin for the core business improved strongly: +50 bps vs cons +20bps although BEI (brand equity investment) fell 40bps as a result of reduced investment behind the failed Scholl / Amopé innovation. Conversely, Mead saw improving topline from -5% Q1 to -1% Q2 (vs MSe -2%) but much weaker margins down -500bps to 19.9% (due to increased investment, pricing corrections and input cost pressure). Despite just 5 weeks of MJN ownership, we note the guidance for "accelerated phasing" of cost savings and implied higher cost savings: "margin expansion over the medium term will be in line with our plan". We expect consensus numbers to fall by 1-2% 2017-20 and an additional ~1% for the sale of the Food Business (helped by lower interest charge).

PM11:55am

Weak 2Q Widely Expected. After conducting over 55 meetings with investors over the last few weeks, we believe most have been waiting for a weak 2Q/3Q/2H (driven by weakness at Mead) to buy the stock. Of course, there remain a number of clear challenges, questions and uncertainties: 1) When will Scholl Amopé finally stabilise? 2) Has RB been overgrowing in both Health and Hygiene (as evidenced by Scholl Amopé)? 3) How much will the Indivior / RBP settlement with the DoJ end up costing (note the £316mn provision)? 4) What will the final impact of the Cyber Attack and Tax Changes in India be to topline? 5) How long will it take for the industry wide glut of Babyfood in China to clear? (see our landmark The Cradle will Rock report 16th August 2017). 6) Are the Mead corrective measures on pricing, super premium innovation and channel changes working? But we continue to believe that the main issues are transitional rather than structural, that near term concerns are presenting a standout opportunity and The Real Prize is RB 2020 (29 June). In our view by 2020, RB should be one of the fastest growing names in Global Staples, with superior returns and cash generation.

BE12:06pm

New laws vs. existing MDAs
Newly enacted laws in Tanzania could significantly impact the economic interests of Acacia across its asset portfolio. Mineral Development Agreements (MDAs) do contain legal protection but it's highly unlikely for Acacia to come out without any compromise. The level of uncertainty around timing and a wide degree of potential outcomes leave too much risk on the table under worst case scenarios despite ~17% share price plunge post results. Therefore we maintain our Sell/High risk rating with revised PT of £2.1/share.

BE12:07pm

wo-thirds of value potentially at risk
Permanent concentrate export ban leading to suspension of all activities at Bulyanhulu and Buzwagi could erode £1.00 (~48%) from our price target. On top of that 16% free carry by Government of Tanzania (GoT) per new laws could dent another £0.40 (~19%) in our PT in the absence of any capital recovery mechanism. Removal of VAT refund and potential for GoT to buy up to 50% of mining assets is even harder to quantify at this stage.
Looks like a complex and time consuming negotiation because
1) GoT is disputing the quantity/value of gold contained in concentrate; 2) ACAA haven't yet received copies of either of Presidential committee reports; 3) GoT intends to negotiate only with majority shareholder (ABX.N; US$16.19; 1; 21 Jul 17; 16:00) meaning ACAA haven't got a seat at the table. Moreover negotiations haven't yet started; 4) Industry was given a very brief (~1 day) consultation period for proposed changes in law; 5) New laws probably need some supplementary provisions to provide clarity and execution mechanisms.
Operations and exploration strong but clouded by regulations
2Q/1H 17 scorecard was strong despite a difficult backdrop. Cost control despite low sales volume due to stockpiling was impressive. Exploration update was also encouraging with potential for another golden banana like area at Gokona u/g. The market is unlikely to appreciate the underlying business till a stable regulatory environment is established, in our view.

BE12:07pm

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Recent regulatory changes include 1) Government's right to renegotiate existing mineral development agreements at its discretion; 2) minimum and non-dilutable 16% free carried interest of govt. in all mining projects; 3) govt. can acquire up to 50% of any mining asset commensurate with tax benefits; 4) removal of input VAT refund; 5) increase in royalties to 6% from 4%; 6) local beneficiation and procurement; 7) constraints on off-shore bank accounts; 8) government lien over material extracted from mines; 9) 1% clearance fee to obtain export clearance
